#Text=Sydney ( Nova Scotia )
#Text=Sydney is a city of 32,000 people ( 2011 ) .
#Text=Itthe main port on Cape Breton Island , in Nova Scotia .
#Text=Understand
#Text=This former industrial city 's main industries today are in customer support call centres and tourism .

#Text=Tourism in Sydney has boomed as a result of significant government investment in cruise ship facilities and a waterfront revitalization plan through which a boardwalk and marinas were constructed , as was the world 's largest fiddle .
#Text=History
#Text=Sydney was founded in 1785 by the British .
#Text=Sydney served as the Cape Breton Island colony 's capital , until 1820 , when the colony merged with Nova Scotia and the capital moved to Halifax .
#Text=A rapid population expansion occurred just after the turn of the 20th century , when Sydney was home to one of North America 's main steel mills .
#Text=During both the First and Second World Wars , it was a major staging area for England-bound convoys .
#Text=The post-war period , there was a major decline in the number of people employed at the Dominion Steel and Coal Corporation ( DOSCO ) steel mill .
#Text=The Nova Scotia and Canadian governments had to nationalize it in 1967 to save the region 's biggest employer , forming the new crown corporation called the Sydney Steel Corporation ( SYSCO ) .
#Text=The city 's population has steadily decreased since the early 1970s as Sydney suffered an economic decline as local coal and steel industries underwent significant changes .

#Text=The closure of the SYSCO and the Cape Breton Development Corporation 's coal mines in 2000-2001 have resulted in attempts by the municipal , provincial and federal governments to diversify the area economy .
#Text=Climate
#Text=Sydney experiences a cool summer , and windy , wet and stormy winter .
#Text=February is the year 's coldest month on average , and August is the year 's warmest month on average .
#Text=While occasional thunderstorms and other rains can occur in summer , June through August are Sydney 's driest months on average .
#Text=Sydney 's average annual precipitation cycle reflects these realities ; the year 's driest month , on average , is July ; its wettest month , on average , is December .
#Text=Average annual precipitation in Sydney is over 1500mm , virtually the highest found anywhere in Canada outside coastal British Columbia .
#Text=Snowfall is heavy , averaging nearly 300 cm per winter season .
#Text=However , winter-season storms are variable , and can bring changing precipitation types , commonly from ice/snow to rain and possibly back to ice/snow .
#Text=A winter storm can bring accumulating snow , followed by heavy rain , then a brief return to snow or ice , resulting in no or minimal additional snow accumulation .

#Text=Overall , Sydney 's climate is moderately cold and strikingly variable , wet , stormy and windy from fall to early spring ( October to March ) , and more stable and drier in summer ( June to August ) .
#Text=By plane
#Text=J.A. Douglas McCurdy
#Text=Sydney Airport
#Text=( YQY ) .
#Text=is served year round by Air Canada with prop service to Halifax and seasonal CRJ service to Montreal .
#Text=During the summer the airport is served by Air Saint-Pierre ( with flights from Saint-Pierre and Miquelon ) and Sunwing Airlines ( with flights from Toronto ) .
#Text=By car
#Text=Driving to Sydney can be done by crossing the Canso Causeway which links the island to the Nova Scotia mainland at Auld 's Cove ( on the mainland ) and Port Hawkesbury ( on Cape Breton ) .
#Text=From there you have two options : the slightly longer but straighter Highways 105 and 125 or the shorter but twistier Route 4 .
#Text=By boat
#Text=North Sydney is the site of the Marine Atlantic terminal which serves as the main connection to Newfoundland .
#Text=From the ferry terminal it is about a 20 minute drive on Highway 125 to Sydney .
#Text=Get around
#Text=Most sights within the downtown are within walking distance , however most major tourist sights are well outside of the city and require a car or pre-arranged tour bus .
#Text=Tourist Information Center , 77 Kings Rd , ☏ +1 902-563-4636 .
#Text=9AM-6PM .
#Text=Transit Cape Breton .
#Text=13 routes through the island .
#Text=Adult fares range from $ 1.25 to $ 5.00 .
#Text=Fares for seniors 55 & up and children 5-12 range from $ 1.00 to $ 4.75 .
#Text=See
#Text=Although Sydney is the centre of Cape Breton , it lacks major tourist sites itself .
#Text=A couple of things to see are :
#Text=Two private homes dating to the earliest settlement of the city , Jost House and Cossitt House , remain in the downtown area of Sydney .
#Text=Wentworth Park , a 5-minute walk south from the downtown core , is worth a visit .
#Text=Merchant Marine Memorial Statue , 246 Esplanade .
#Text=A roadside attraction .
#Text=Old Sydney Society , 175 Charlotte St , ☏ +1 902-539-1572 .
#Text=Museum .
#Text=St Patrick 's Museum , 87 Esplanade , ☏ +1 902-562-8237 .
#Text=Do
#Text=Casino Nova Scotia - Sydney 's Neighbourhood Casino , 525 George St , ☏ +1 902-563-7777 .
#Text=Got plenty of money and no grasp of statistics ?
#Text=The government would love to see you !
#Text=There 's a restaurant on-site .
#Text=Buy
#Text=The Sydney marine terminal and Charlotte Street have an abundance of arts and crafts stores selling traditional Cape Breton souvenirs .
#Text=Eat
#Text=Sydney has many well established restaurants , most with menus full of classic seafood favourites .
#Text=Celtic Junction Bar and Grille ( inside the Sydney casino ) .
#Text=This restaurant features a large menu consisting of a good mixture of diner classics and newer ' fusion-fare ' .
#Text=Because it is located inside the casino , it is off limits to those under 19 .
#Text=Kiju 's Restaurant , 50 Maillard St , Membertou B1S 3W3 , ☏ +1 902-562-6220 , fax : +1 902-564-4921 .
#Text=Su - Th 11AM-9PM , F - Sa 11AM-10PM .
#Text=Fresh ideas and local ingredients , pub style classics , kid ’s meals and finer fare .
#Text=In Membertou Trade and Convention Centre , near the Hampton Inn Sydney .
#Text=Drink
#Text=Breton Brewing Co. , 364 Keltic Drive , ☏ +1 902-270-4677 .
#Text=A local craft brewery that sells pints in the tasting room .
#Text=Sleep
#Text=Sydney is home to a handful of places to rest your head ranging from small motels to larger hotels .
#Text=Beacon Motel , 294 Keltic Drive , toll-free : +1-866-562-8282 .
#Text=Cheaper motel located 10 minutes outside of the downtown core .
#Text=No website ; call to make reservations .
#Text=Cambridge Suites , 380 Esplanade , ☏ +1902 562-6500 , toll-free : +1-800-565-9466 , fax : +1902 564-6011 .
#Text=Although the nicest hotel in the city , it lacks a swimming pool so it might not be very family friendly , which might be a selling point for busy business travellers .
#Text=Hearthstone Inn Sydney , 560 Kings Road , ☏ +1 902-539-8101 , toll-free : +1 800-422-8025 , ✉ reservations@hearthstonesydney.com .
#Text=Hotel with free high-speed Internet , restaurant and lounge , heated pool , exercise room , executive suite , courtyard and free parking .
#Text=Holiday Inn Sydney - Waterfront , 300 Esplanade , ☏ +1902 562-7500 .
#Text=Check-in : 3PM , check-out : 11AM .
#Text=This hotel features large conference facilities and ballrooms , a large swimming pool , waterslide , gym and sauna .
#Text=Travelodge Sydney , 480 Kings Road , fax : +1 902-707-4603 .
#Text=This hotel also has a pool , sauna , hot tub , and gym .
#Text=For travellers seeking something with a little more character try one of the many bed and breakfasts in the area
